chapter.summary: Covers the management of pigmented lesions in primary care, including referral of suspected melanoma. It also covers advice on the prevention of malignant melanoma and self-care advice to people at increased risk of developing melanoma.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Evidence on the ABCD and 7-point checklists
Evidence on self-examination for early melanoma detection

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Urgently refer (within 2 weeks) to a dermatologist, plastic surgeon, or other suitable specialist with experience of melanoma diagnosis if:
    • The lesion is suggestive of malignant melanoma (including nodular and amelanotic melanoma). For example:
      • Lesions scoring 3 points or more (based on major features scoring 2 points each and minor features scoring 1 point each) on the 7-point checklist. However, any one feature is adequate to prompt urgent referral.
      • New nodules which are pigmented or vascular in appearance.
      • Nail changes, such as a new pigmented line in the nail or pigmentation under the nail.
    • There is any doubt about the lesion.
    • A skin condition is persistent or slowly evolving and unresponsive, with an uncertain diagnosis, and melanoma is a possibility.
    • A biopsy has confirmed the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Note: if a lesion is suspected to be melanoma, an urgent referral to a dermatologist or other suitable specialist with experience of melanoma diagnosis should be made, and excision in primary care should be avoided.
      • A copy of the pathology report should be sent with the referral correspondence, as there may be details (such as tumour thickness, excision margin) that will specifically influence further management.
  • Routinely refer for risk estimation, education and possible follow up in secondary care (although resources for follow up may be limited) if people are at higher risk (around 10-fold) of melanoma, such as those with:
    • Giant congenital pigmented naevi (risk is highest for those measuring 20 cm in diameter or more).
    • A family history of 3 or more cases of melanoma — refer to a clinical geneticist or specialized dermatology service for counselling. Those with two cases in the family may also benefit, especially if one of the cases had multiple primary melanomas or the atypical mole phenotype.
    • More than 100 normal moles.
    • Atypical moles (particularly if multiple).
  • Referral is not usually required for obviously benign lesions, such as moles and seborrhoeic keratoses. Features which are generally reassuring and suggest a benign lesion include:
    • Regularity of colour, surface, and border (suggests a benign lesion, such as a mole).
    • Rapid growth over days rather than weeks (suggests an underlying pyogenic granuloma rather than malignant change).
    • 'Stuck on' appearance with keratotic plugs on the surface (suggests a seborrhoeic keratosis).
    • Dimpling if bilateral pressure is applied to the lesion (suggests a dermatofibroma).
    • A pigmented lesion in a child (melanoma is very rare in this age group).

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information should I include with referral?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Most regions will have a local referral form for pigmented lesions which should be used, if available. If not, include the following information:
    • Location.
    • Size of lesion.
    • Shape.
    • Colour.
    • How long the lesion has been present.
    • Changes.
    • Symptoms (inflammation, oozing, crusting, bleeding, change in sensation).
    • Palpable lymph nodes.
    • Risk factors for melanoma.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Urgent referral (within 2 weeks)
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in guidelines from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence on Improving outcomes for people with skin tumours including melanoma [NICE, 2006]  and Suspected cancer: recognition and [NICE, 2015a] and the paper Melanoma published by [BMJ Best Practice, 2017a]. 
Referral of someone at increased risk of melanoma
  • This recommendation is based on UK guidelines on Prevention, Diagnosis, Referral, and Management of Melanoma of the Skin and Management of Cutaneous Melanoma [Marsden et al, 2010].
  • Baseline photography should be used for melanocytic lesions which do not need excision [Macbeth, 2015]. 
Reassuring features
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in  [BMJ Best Practice, 2017a].
Information to include with the referral
  • The recommendation on what information to include with a referral is based on expert opinion in guidelines from the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence on Improving outcomes for people with skin tumours including melanoma [NICE, 2006]

subChapters.fullItemName: People at increased risk of melanoma
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage people who are at increased risk of melanoma?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For all people at increased risk of melanoma (for example people with freckles, red hair, or skin which burns in the sun; those with a previous melanoma or family history of skin cancer; people with more than 50 moles; and immunosuppressed people):
    • Advise on prevention of skin cancer. (See Skin Cancer Foundation)
    • Encourage them to perform monthly self-examinations. For more information, see the American Academy of Dermatology website: www.aad.org/public/exams/self.html.
    • Give information on signs and symptoms of suspicious lesions when to access medical advice.
    • Advise people who have had one type of skin cancer that they may develop a new and different lesion.
  • For people at higher risk of melanoma (for example those with a giant congenital pigmented naevus, a strong family history, atypical moles, or more than 100 normal moles), offer advice as above and explain that long-term follow up is recommended (usually with a dermatologist).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This recommendation is based on evidence from non-experimental studies in UK guidelines on the Management of cutaneous melanoma from the British Association of Dermatologists [Marsden et al, 2010], UK guidelines from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence on Improving outcomes for people with skin tumours including melanoma [NICE, 2006], Skin cancer prevention [NICE, 2011] and SIGN guidelines [SIGN, 2017].

subChapters.fullItemName: Prevention and detection of skin cancers
subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give on prevention and detection of skin cancers?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person that enjoying the sun safely (avoiding burning) can provide the benefits of vitamin D without raising the risk of skin cancer.
    • Although excessive sun exposure is the main cause of skin cancer, including melanoma, sun exposure is also the main source of vitamin D. Lack of vitamin D can cause such conditions as rickets and osteomalacia. It is important to balance the benefits of sun exposure with the person's risk of skin cancer, bearing in mind that the time to make sufficient vitamin D is typically less than the time taken to burn. For further information please refer to the CKS topic on Vitamin D deficiency in adults - treatment and prevention.
  • Give general advice to those at risk of skin cancer to avoid excessive sun and ultraviolet (UV) exposure by:
    • Avoiding sunburn.
    • Using clothing to protect against the summer sun.
    • Using a broad-spectrum sunscreen (minimum sun protection factor [SPF] of 15 [only sufficient if applied adequately], but preferably SPF 20–30, with 4- or 5-star UVA protection), provided this does not lead to increased time spent in the sun. Use a water-resistant product if sweating or contact with water is likely.
      • Sunscreen should be applied liberally half an hour before going out, and then reapplied after half an hour and then every 2 hours to ensure protection is adequate. On average, an adult needs around 35 millilitres (2 tablespoons) of sunscreen to cover the whole body. Sunscreen should also be reapplied after being in the water (even if it is labelled 'water resistant') and after towel drying.
    • Avoiding direct, intense sunlight, and finding shade, especially between 11 am and 3 pm.
    • Using these measures not only when abroad in hot climates, but also in the summer in the UK, and when on winter sports holidays.
    • Avoiding tanning booths, tanning, lamps, and sunbeds.
  • In addition to general advice on sun and UV exposure, tailor advice to specific groups of people:
    • Children — protect them with shade, clothing, and SPF 50+ sunscreen. Keep babies out of direct sunlight.
    • Outdoor workers — protect exposed skin in the summer with regular (2-hourly) applications of high-protection sunscreen. Wear a hat that shades the face, neck, and ears. If possible, avoid the sun from 11 am to 3 pm and take breaks in the shade.
  • Advise people to seek medical advice if they have a mole which is:
    • Getting bigger.
    • Changing shape — particularly if the edge is becoming irregular.
    • Changing colour — getting darker, becoming patchy, or multi-shaded.
    • Persistently itchy or painful.
    • Bleeding or becoming crusty.
    • Inflamed and not settling.
  • For further information, people can access the Cancer Research SunSmart campaign at www.sunsmart.org.uk. This provides information on many issues, including sunscreens, sunburn, moles and skin cancer, vitamin D, and winter sports.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Vitamin D deficiency
  • This information is based on a consensus vitamin D position statement from NICE and Cancer Research UK [NICE, 2014; Cancer Research UK, 2016b; BMJ Best Practice, 2017a].
Advice on the prevention of skin cancers
  • These recommendations are based on expert opinion in guidelines from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence on Improving outcomes for people with skin cancer including melanoma [NICE, 2006] and Skin cancer prevention [NICE, 2016b], evidence from randomized controlled trials in guidelines from the Royal College of Physicians and the British Association of Dermatologists on the Prevention, diagnosis, referral, and management of melanoma of the skin [Marsden et al, 2010].
  • People should be advised to avoid sun beds as the risk of melanoma increases with the number of sunbed sessions, especially if initiated at under 35 years of age [Boniol, 2012]. 
  • There is a difference in opinion between expert organizations in relation to the recommended sun protection factor (SPF) that should be used. The Royal College of Physicians and British Association of Dermatologists guidelines recommend an SPF30 and either 4 or 5 star UVA protection [BAD, 2013b], whereas guidance from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) recommends a minimum SPF of 15 and 4 star UVA protection  [NICE, 2016b] . However, NICE discuss that SPF 15 is sufficient if applied adequately, but to take into account behavioural factors (such as insufficient quantities being applied).
Advice on the detection of malignant melanoma
  • This recommendation is based on information on melanoma provided by Cancer Research UK [Cancer Research UK, 2016b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage benign pigmented lesions?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If there is a high degree of confidence that the lesion is benign, reassure the person. Provide them with information (ideally written) regarding the changes that may subsequently suggest malignant transformation and instruct them to return if any such changes occur or if the lesion continues to cause them concern.
  • If there is a low degree of suspicion that the lesion is melanoma (for example it scores 1 or 2 points on the 7-point checklist), advise the person to monitor the lesion (explaining the features to watch for) and to come back if they notice any changes. Ideally, measurement should be made with photographs and a marker scale and/or ruler. Review after 8 weeks. Alternatively, an in-house referral to a colleague for a second opinion is advised. Ideally this will be a GP or GPSI in Dermatology who is able to review the lesion under a Dermatoscope. 
  • Give advice on prevention of melanoma.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Reassurance
  • This recommendation is based on a guideline from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence on Improving outcomes for people with skin tumours including melanoma [NICE, 2006] and guidelines from the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network on Cutaneous melanoma [SIGN, 2017].
Monitoring
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a guideline from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence on Referral for suspected cancer [NICE, 2005] and Melanoma: Summary of NICE Guideline [Macbeth, 2015].
